data.name: Five Fundamental Comonads
data.description:
This is a dual to [Five Fundamental Monads](https://www.codewars.com/kata/five-fundamental-monads/haskell). A co-kata, maybe? ;-)

---

In this kata we will implement five of the most fundamental comonads. 

Newcomers to Haskell find monads to be one of the most intimidating concepts but on a basic level - they are not too difficult to understand. Comonads, however, might not be the case ;-)

A datatype forms a comonad if it is possible to complete the following definitions such that the comonad laws (described below) hold. There's nothing more to it! For a more intuitive understanding then there are **no** plethora of tutorials which use (sometimes wild) analogies to explain this concept, though (because everyone's attention is diverted to monads. A sad story for comonads ;-)).

```
class Functor w => Comonad w where
	extract :: w a -> a
  -- you can choose to implement at least one of the below
	extend :: (w a -> b) -> w a -> w b
  duplicate :: w a -> w (w a)
```

Comonad laws

```haskell
-- if you have implemented extract
extend extract      = id
extract . extend f  = f
extend f . extend g = extend (f . extend g)

-- if you have implemented extend
extract . duplicate      = id
fmap extract . duplicate = id
duplicate . duplicate    = fmap duplicate . duplicate

-- if you have implemented both extract and extend, you also need to satisfy these laws
extract . duplicate      = id
fmap extract . duplicate = id
duplicate . duplicate    = fmap duplicate . duplicate
```

It turns out that many different types of computation can be encapsulated by comonads. For example the `Store` comonad produces a getter and setter for a field in a larger structure (also called a `lens`) and `Stream` can produce a infinite stream of values.

The five we will implement here are `Identity` (i.e `Co-indentity`), `Stream` (i.e `Co-list`), `Store` (i.e `Co-state`), `Traced` (i.e `Co-reader`) and `Env` (i.e `Co-writer`).

Note: `Control.Comonad` is disabled.
